repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Industrial Free Zone
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Industrial Free Zone
            Development Project in Dominican Republic were as follows:
            overall outcome of the project was rated satisfactory,
            project sustainability was likely, and the performance of
            the Bank and the Borrower was also rated satisfactory. The
            most fundamental lesson learned is that private sector
            investment projects - including enclave undertakings such as
            the Industrial Free Zone (IFZs) -- cannot develop to their
            full potential in the absence of sound sector policies.
            Private investors in this Project suffered -- and will
            continue to suffer -- because of the underdeveloped state of
            the local financial system, and the reliance on a poorly
            capitalized banking system to finance "lumpy",
            capital-intensive investments. Indeed, a broader set of
            debt, quasi-equity, and equity instruments may be required
            for the optimal financing of such projects. Moreover,
            notwithstanding the successes of the IFZ model to date, the
            potential for using IFZ growth to support more widespread
            productive development continues unrealized because
            industrial sector policies constrain the integration of
            domestic factors into the export sector. As a result,
            industrial and service sector employment (including
            employment for the poor) and national export earnings are
            lower than they could be. The need for financial and
            industrial sector reform has become even more urgent with
            the advent of North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA)
            and increased global competition for IFZ investment based
            upon low-cost labor. These developments imply that the
            continued success of the IFZs in the Dominican Republic will
            be contingent upon successful measures to raise value added
            in the production chain, inter alia through worker education
            and training.

repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Industrial Free Zone
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Industrial Free Zone Development
            Project will assist the Government to meet term financing
            expansion needs of private operating industrial free zones
            and the initial construction phase of new zones. The project
            will also strengthen the monitoring and control of
            environmental impact of free zones. To achieve these goals
            the project will finance: (i) the construction of factory
            shells and office park structures; and (ii) the development
            of new land, including infrastructure and services. The
            technical assistance component will aid the executing
            agency, the Investment Fund for Economic Development (FIDE),
            to implement the project; strengthen the National Council of
            Free Zones (NCFZ) in regulating all free zones; and support
            the Investment Promotion Council (IPC) in carrying out
            policy studies and reinforcing backward linkages.
